sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The familyLegionellaceae is composed of a single genus, Legionella, and comprises 66 validly named species and three subspecies (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/genus/legionella) (Table 1). Legionella pneumophila, Legionella micdadei, Legionella bozemanii, and Legionella longbeachae are the most important species from a clinical standpoint, with L. pneumophila causing more than 90% of Legionnaires’ disease (LD) globally, apart from Australia and New Zealand, where L. longbeachae predominates (1). The Legionellaceae are most closely related to the Coxiellaceae, and these two families comprise the order Legionellales within the class Gammaproteobacteria, phylum “Proteobacteria” phyl. nov. Coxiella burnetii, the agent of Q fever, shares many characteristics with L. pneumophila, including intracellular parasitism and close homologies with several virulence genes (2). Tatlockia and Fluoribacter are old and no-longer-used synonyms for the Legionellaceae (3). A number of Legionella-like amoebal pathogens (LLAP) have been described that only grow within free-living amoebae. Legionella lytica is an LLAP that has been shown to cause human disease, and four have been assigned as novel Legionella spp.; three of these four have been grown axenically at low temperature (4).

Due to the increased use of whole-genome sequencing (WGS),L. pneumophila is regularly sequenced, and these sequences are available through sites like NCBI (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/datasets/genomes/) and ENA (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/browser/home). Genomic analysis shows that L. pneumophila contains several eukaryote-like genes, some of which allow the creation of a bacterium-friendly intracellular environment by subverting the normal cellular machinery of amoebae and macrophages (5). Analysis of the L. pneumophila genome in particular shows that it is a genetically diverse species and that some virulent strains are disseminated worldwide (5, 6). The genes and structure of the lipopolysaccharide core region and an O side chain that predominate in clinical isolates of L. pneumophila serogroup (Sg) 1 may be the reason why this serogroup predominates as a cause of LD, as it is involved in adhesion to the host cell (5, 7). Genomic sequences of many other Legionella spp., including L. longbeachae, have been reported (8). There are novel Legionella species identified that are not yet validly published (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/genus/legionella).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENT
sect2.para: TheLegionellaceae are a family of mesophilic, motile, asaccharolytic, obligately aerobic, nutritionally fastidious Gram-negative rods that share growth dependence for L-cysteine, growth enhancement by iron, and cellular branched-chain fatty acids and ubiquinones imparting acid fastness, which are unusual for Gram-negative bacteria (9). L. pneumophila is the most extensively studied of the Legionella spp., with relatively little known about most of the other Legionella spp. Almost all Legionella spp. have been isolated from aqueous environmental sources, and about a third of the 66 validly named species have been isolated from both humans and the environment. It is assumed that the natural reservoir of all the Legionellaceae is aqueous or soil environments and that humans are accidental hosts. While almost all Legionella spp. have been isolated from environmental water sources, L. longbeachae appears to be mainly a soil organism equipped with genes that may aid its residence/pathogenesis in soil insects or worms (10). Environmental L. pneumophila is a facultative intracellular parasite of several free-living amoebae, such as Acanthamoeba and Naegleria species, existing in microbial consortia in biofilms and free-flowing water (11).

L. pneumophila grows at a temperature range from 20 to 42°C, optimally at 35 to 37°C. Other Legionella spp. infecting humans may have more restricted growth temperatures, including L. steelei and the LLAPs that do not grow at temperatures greater than 35°C (12). Growth on solid media is enhanced by increased humidity. Incubation in 2 to 5% CO2 can enhance the growth of some Legionella spp. Bacterial phenotype, including immunogenicity, cell size, and virulence, can be altered by growth at different temperatures (9).

Amino acids are energy sources used by theLegionellaceae growing in vitro. Primary isolation of almost all known Legionella spp. requires medium supplementation with L-cysteine. Iron supplementation of growth media is required for optimal growth. Growth of L. pneumophila is enhanced, via an unknown, nonnutritive mechanism, by addition of α-ketoglutarate (0.1%) to media.

Growth ofL. pneumophila in artificial media can be inhibited by a number of factors. These include high (100 mM, or 0.6%) NaCl concentrations, toxic peroxides, products of other bacteria and fungi, and some lipids (9). In addition, optimal growth occurs over a very narrow pH range from 6.7 to 6.9. Solid growth media contain activated charcoal to inactivate toxic lipids and peroxides, and an organic buffer [morpholinepropanesulfonic acid (MOPS) or N-(2-acetamido)-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid (ACES)] to reduce sodium content and provide the required pH. Preparation of growth media for Legionella spp. can be complex and is usually best left to competent commercial sources or specialized laboratories.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY, TRANSMISSION, AND PATHOGENESIS
sect2.para: LD was first recognized following an outbreak of pneumonia at a convention of the Pennsylvania State Legionnaires in Philadelphia, PA, in July 1976, with a 15% fatality rate (13, 14). Joseph McDade and colleagues at the CDC determined that a novel Gram-negative bacterium was the cause of the outbreak (15). Neither the disease nor the bacterium was actually novel, with the first known outbreak of LD occurring in 1957 (16). The bacterium had been reported multiple times since the first Legionella species was identified in 1943 (15). It was initially described as a rickettsial-like organism that only grew in guinea pig blood and embryonated chicken eggs and was initially classified as part of the Tatlockia genus (16).

Environmental studies have found that the bacterium is widespread in natural bodies of water including lakes, rivers, and hot springs (17–19). From these natural sources, it can spread into water distribution networks (20). Legionella spp. can also live and multiply within free-living amoebae, and as a result, these otherwise fastidious bacteria are protected from challenging environmental conditions such as heat and biocides (15, 21).

Legionella-infected amoebae are often found in complex consortia of microorganisms within biofilms (22). Legionella spp. are present in very low concentrations in freely flowing cold water and biocide-treated waters but can multiply in warm, and especially stagnant, water. Devices that aerosolize these contaminated waters serve to disseminate the bacteria. In contrast, L. longbeachae infections appear to be acquired mainly through exposure to soil, especially some types of potting soil (23).

L. pneumophila causes more than 90% of community-acquired LD, predominantly by L. pneumophila Sg 1 (24). The Pontiac or Dresden monoclonal antibody subgroup (Mab 3-1) of L. pneumophila Sg 1 constitutes 80 to 90% of clinical isolates of this serogroup. Just a few clonal sequence types of L. pneumophila Sg 1 strains are responsible for about 50% of sporadic community-acquired infections (6, 25). Several L. pneumophila clinical isolates are uncommon in the environment, whereas most L. pneumophila strains commonly found in the environment are unusual causes of LD (25, 26). Infections caused by L. pneumophila Sg 1 are less common in health care-related compared to community-acquired LD, but the death rate is often higher in health care-acquired LD (27).

Infection is acquired by aerosol inhalation of contaminated water, although microaspiration may also be a mechanism for acquiring the disease (13). Most community outbreaks of LD are from Legionella-contaminated cooling towers or other aerosol-generating devices. Contaminated potable water systems can also be a source of disease, although these sources are not usually the cause of explosive outbreaks, but rather of more sporadic or prolonged outbreaks (28). In 2018, Orkis et al. (29) reviewed the literature and identified residential potable water, large building water systems, and, interestingly, car travel as contributors to a substantial proportion of sporadic LD cases. Car travel may relate to travel-associated LD through air conditioning systems (30). Some occupational settings, such as industrial facilities equipped with cooling towers or coolant systems, have been described as the most common source for acquiring LD at work (31).

Despite the ubiquity ofLegionella spp. in the environment, LD is an unusual cause of pneumonia. Passive reporting indicates that the disease incidence is between 9 to 24 cases per million people per year (32, 33). This rate may be an underestimate, as a German study found that the annual rate was 180 to 360 cases per million, equivalent to about 4% of community-acquired pneumonia cases, with a similar percentage for hospitalized cases (34). Underdiagnosis of LD is common in the United States due to lack of utilization of laboratory testing and insensitivity of some laboratory diagnostic methods (35). Sporadic community-acquired LD is much more common than outbreak-associated disease, with only about 4% of U.S. cases being associated with known clusters (24, 36). About 20% of LD cases are associated with travel, both nationally and internationally, and there have been cases associated with cruise ships. There are seasonal peaks in the warmer months (from the late spring until early fall); about 60% of reported U.S. and European cases occur between June and October (24, 36, 37).

The incubation period of LD is estimated to be between 2 and 14 days, with a median value of about 4 days. A study of a large outbreak extended the incubation period to as long as 19 days, with a median value of 7 days (26, 38). Epidemiologic case definitions for LD used by public health authorities can be found online (39).

L. pneumophila causes disease by infecting human mononuclear cells, primarily alveolar macrophages (21). The molecular and cellular pathogenesis of L. pneumophila has been studied in detail, but little is known about the pathogenic mechanism of the other Legionella spp., except that of L. longbeachae, which has been the subject of a few studies (40–42). L. pneumophila injects hundreds of pathogenicity effectors, via a type IV secretion system, into macrophages almost as soon as the bacterium makes contact with the phagocytic cell. Bacterial strains lacking this type IV secretion system, termed Dot or Icm, are avirulent. The injected effectors hijack normal cellular host defenses that would ordinarily destroy the bacterium within a fused phagolysosome. Instead, the virulent bacteria reside in a nonfused phagosome that is associated with host ribosomes, and rather than being killed, bacteria derive nutrients from the cell and multiply within the specialized phagosome. After multiplying many thousandfold within the phagocyte, the bacteria effect cell death. At the same time, the bacteria change their phenotype to become very motile, small, and primed for invading adjacent uninfected phagocytes. The bacteria possess other secretion systems, by which they secrete several proteases and other potentially toxic substances, many of which are either proinflammatory or tissue destructive. Intracellular iron acquisition is important for bacterial survival and growth of cells, with several bacterial effectors aiding in iron acquisition. The host response to the bacterium, as well as secreted toxic substances, produces intense inflammation that destroys host tissues in the lung. The bacteria are controlled primarily by innate and acquired cellular immunity. Detailed descriptions of pathogenesis can be found elsewhere (43).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: LD is a type of bacterial pneumonia caused byL. pneumophila and other Legionella spp. The pneumonia ranges in severity from mild to fatal, with an average fatality rate of 12% (27, 44). Major risk factors for the disease include endogenous or exogenous suppression of the cellular immune system, cigarette smoking, travel, use of well water, chronic heart or lung disease, and chronic renal failure. Patients at particularly high risk of LD are those receiving high-dosage corticosteroids, those with solid organ transplants, and those receiving anti-tumor necrosis factor therapy for a variety of autoimmune diseases (13).

LD cannot be readily distinguished from other forms of community-acquired pneumonia by clinical, roentgenographic, or nonspecific laboratory studies (13). Several attempts at developing a clinical scoring system to distinguish LD from other pneumonias have failed. Severity of pneumonia at presentation, underlying diseases, and promptness of specific antibiotic therapy are important prognostic factors. Promptly treated, LD can be cured in 95 to 99% of cases in an otherwise healthy person. Untreated disease causes death in about 15% of patients, among whom up to 75% are severely immunocompromised (44).

Prospective, randomized controlled studies of adequate size have not been performed to determine the optimal therapy for LD, so great reliance is placed on experimental tissue culture and animal model studies, as well as results of nonrandomized studies (44). Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, levofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, and moxifloxacin appear to have roughly equivalent efficacies for immunocompetent outpatients with mild LD (44). The fluoroquinolone antimicrobials, especially levofloxacin, and azithromycin are the drugs of choice for severe disease and for immunocompromised patients (44). Antimicrobial therapy with more than one agent is sometimes used but is of questionable benefit and may be harmful (44, 45).

New antibiotics are currently being studied. For example, tigecycline alone or in combination with azithromycin has been suggested for patients with severe disease refractory to conventional first-line antibiotics (46).

Pontiac fever is an acute influenza-like illness associated with exposure toLegionella species-containing environmental aerosols (44). The etiology and pathogenesis of this disease are unknown, but it appears to be associated with inhalation of bacterial toxins, such as endotoxin, or perhaps an acute allergic reaction to a bacterium. Since multiple microorganisms and endotoxin are found in aerosols causing Pontiac fever, it is unclear if Legionella spp. play any role in disease causation. Pontiac fever is self-limited, with no reported deaths, little to no need for hospitalization, and no need for antibiotic therapy. No specific diagnostic testing is needed.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, STORAGE, AND TRANSPORT
sect2.para: Sputum and other lower respiratory tract specimens are the most common sources ofLegionella spp. Other sources include pleural fluid and blood. Rare sources have included pericardial fluid and specimens from kidney, liver, spleen, myocardium, respiratory sinuses, skin and soft tissues, wounds, peritoneal fluid, prosthetic and native heart valves, joint fluids, bone marrow, and the intestine. Culture of sputum, including induced sputum, bronchoscopy specimens, lung biopsy specimens, and pleural fluid, should be routine for laboratory diagnosis of LD. Culture of sputum or other lower respiratory tract secretions, second in yield to lung biopsy specimens, should be performed for optimal detection of Legionella infection. It is preferable to collect respiratory samples prior to specific antibiotic therapy to ensure the best chance of growing Legionella spp. Pleural fluid has low yield (<10%) but should be cultured if available. Culture of other specimen types for Legionella spp. is not indicated unless there is a high clinical suspicion of the disease affecting these sites or specific laboratory evidence of disease elsewhere, such as a positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT).

Microscopic or visual inspection of a sample should not be used as a criterion for processing specimens (47). A positive NAAT may be used as a criterion for selective culture. Patient isolates are often the only way to compare with environmental isolates and identify the source of infection.

Urine for antigen detection should be collected in a sterile container during the acute phase of disease to allow the best chance of positivity. There is no published information on the effects of preservatives such as boric acid on urinary antigen assays, but boric acid can preserve samples at room temperature for extended periods. Longer transport times may require specimen refrigeration. Frozen urine samples are stable for several months to decades (48).

Blood for serum antibody testing is collected in standard tubes and transported at room temperature (49). Test performance is not adversely affected by storage of clotted unseparated blood at room temperature for several days. Long-term storage of aliquots to allow parallel testing without multiple cycles of freeze-thawing, which can lower antibody levels, is at –20°C. This testing is usually performed in a reference laboratory with access to control material.

Legionella spp. are hardy and generally survive for up to a week in clinical specimens. Sputum and other respiratory tract specimens, including lung biopsy specimens, should be collected in sterile containers and promptly transported to the laboratory at room temperature. Transportation and storage should be at 2 to 5°C if more than a several-hour delay is anticipated before specimen processing. Long-term storage is best at –80°C, although this can reduce bacterial concentrations to below the level of detection when the starting concentration is low or the specimen is excessively dilute. Repeated freeze-thawing is harmful to the bacteria. Some tissues, especially the spleen, contain growth-preventing substances so must be processed promptly, as even overnight storage at 2 to 5°C dramatically reduces culture yield (note that this is not true of lung specimens).

Valid data on the stability ofLegionella DNA in clinical samples have not been published. Regardless, special conditions for transportation of respiratory materials used solely for Legionella spp. NAATs do not appear to be required. Lower respiratory tract specimens are superior to nasopharyngeal aspirates (50). General guidelines for the transport and preanalytical storage of these specimen types are found in ASM Clinical Microbiology Procedures Handbook (48).

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: The morphology ofL. pneumophila found in lung and sputum is a short Gram-negative bacillus 3 to 5 μm in length (Fig. 1). This is different from that observed for the bacterium taken from a culture plate, which is usually a long filamentous bacillus 10 to 25 μm in length. Gram staining is discussed in the culture section; direct immunofluorescence microscopy is the most sensitive and specific microscopic method for direct visualization of L. pneumophila in tissues and sputum, although Gimenez staining can also be used (Fig. 1) (48). Optimal sensitivity and specificity require exacting staining methods and expertise and therefore direct visualization is now rarely used for direct examination, except perhaps in the examination of autopsy lung specimens.

sect1.title: Antigen Detection
sect1.para: LD due toL. pneumophila Sg 1 may be diagnosed by detection of bacterial antigenuria (32, 48, 51). Several immunoassays are commercially available for this purpose, the most convenient of which are rapid single-test immunochromatographic tests (ICTs). ICTs are manufactured by many companies, and three are FDA cleared (Alere, BinaxNOW; SA Scientific, SAS Legionella; and Meridian, TRU Legionella) (50). There are also enzyme immunoassays (EIAs) on the market. The strength of these assays is their detection of infection due to L. pneumophila Sg 1 (32, 48, 52). However, ICTs can be up to 40% less sensitive than the EIA. The ability to test a single specimen quickly, combined with ease of use, may make up for the lower sensitivity of ICT (53). Clinical test performance for all assays is dependent on presence of the Pontiac/Dresden monoclonal subtype of L. pneumophila Sg 1 (48). Patients with severe L. pneumophila Sg 1 LD, requiring intensive care and ventilator assistance, are most likely to have a positive urinary antigen test. Test sensitivity in this patient group is probably in the range of 90 to 95% if infected with a Pontiac/Dresden monoclonal subtype. On the other hand, urine testing may detect only 50% of outpatients with mild disease caused by the same monoclonal subtype. Only 40% of hospitalized patients with other L. pneumophila Sg 1 subtypes, and fewer than 5 to 40% of those with infections caused by other serogroups and species, are detected (48). Urinary antigen peaks between day 6 and 10 after onset of disease symptoms, so sensitivity is improved if urine is tested within this window, although it can remain positive for >25 days (54).

Sensitivity can be enhanced for both ICT and EIA by concentrating urine using ultrafiltration prior to testing. In some studies, this has increased test sensitivity by 20 to 30% without affecting specificity (32, 38, 48, 55). Prolonging incubation time for the BinaxNOW assay to 60 min also increases sensitivity without decreasing specificity (32, 48). Test sensitivity may decrease if specimens are frozen for months before being tested (32, 48).

Urine antigen assays have specificities in the range of 98.4 to 99.7% (56). False-positive tests can be due to rheumatoid arthritis-like factors in urine, freeze-thawing of urine, and excessive urinary sediment and have been thought to be low, although a recent publication put false positives as high as 23% (57). Regardless, positives may be confirmed by boiling urine and then clarifying it by centrifugation; although these steps may increase test specificity, they are not mentioned in manufacturer’s instructions. The Legionella community is in the process of identifying a procedure for urine boiling and is evaluating this approach with a panel of commercial kits, including EIA and ICT using both visual and automated reading. Patients who previously had LD may continue to excrete urinary antigen for days to months after successful treatment (54). Such prolonged urinary excretion is not evidence of treatment failure, and it is mainly found in immunocompromised patients (58).

sect1.title: Molecular Diagnosis of LD
sect1.para: Nucleic acid-based detection ofLegionella spp. in sputum, urine, and blood has been successfully used, with detection of L. pneumophila being the most extensively studied. Molecular diagnosis is a more sensitive method of diagnosis than culture (59). Test sensitivities have been estimated to be 80 to 100% and 30 to 50% for lower respiratory tract secretions and serum, respectively; test specificities are estimated to be >90% (39, 59). Sputum digestion using proteinase K while mixing at high speed prior to DNA extraction may increase yield and eliminate PCR inhibitors (40, 60).

Both conventional and real-time assays have been utilized (61, 62). Most laboratories use the macrophage infectivity protein (mip) gene target to detect L. pneumophila. Legionella spp. are most commonly detected using an rRNA gene target, usually the 16S rRNA gene, although the 23S rRNA gene is claimed to have advantages (63). The wzm target can be used to specifically detect L. pneumophila serogroup 1 (64). A multiplex assay that detects L. pneumophila Sg 1 (wzm), L. pneumophila (mip), and Legionella spp. (ssrA) is a sensitive and specific assay for use with clinical specimens (65). Multiplex assays are most commonly used because they have no disadvantage over uniplex methods, although one study showed the superiority of a nucleic acid sequence-based amplification (NASBA) uniplex assay over a multiplex format (66, 67). For laboratories testing specimens from immunocompromised patients, it is important to test for both L. pneumophila and Legionella spp. other than L. pneumophila, or for Legionella spp. alone, because there is a relatively high frequency of LD not caused by L. pneumophila in this population. Public health laboratories may prefer to perform a two- or three-target assay, to allow rapid detection of L. pneumophila Sg 1 infections (65, 68). Molecular typing of L. pneumophila is often possible directly from the primary specimen, and can be useful in outbreak investigations (69). In regions where L. longbeachae infection is common, NAATs can be used to detect this organism directly from clinical specimens (70).

There are now FDA-cleared commercial NAATs forLegionella detection marketed in the United States as part of respiratory panels, including the BioFire pneumonia panel and the Curetis Unyvero LRT panel (71–73).

The added benefit of NAAT detection ofLegionella spp. in sputum over urine antigen testing is the 11% greater yield compared to urine testing alone (74). The performance of NAAT for detection of non-Sg 1 L. pneumophila is significantly better than urine antigen testing (74).

A problem with molecular detection ofLegionella species in clinical specimens has been the inability to type L. pneumophila for epidemiologic purposes if the organism fails to grow. This is now possible using a nested sequence-based typing (n-SBT) method (75). Descriptions of primers and detailed protocols are available online and can be accessed by contacting the database curators at the UK Health Security Agency (legionella-sbt@ukhsa.gov.uk).

BecauseLegionella spp. are commonly found in water, contamination of almost any molecular reagent with Legionella nucleic acid is a concern. False-positive NAATs for Legionella spp. have been attributed to contaminated commercially produced “pure” water and nucleic acid extraction columns (75, 76). Since sequencing of false-positive products yields Legionella species sequences, the possibility of contamination cannot be excluded by the ability to sequence the product and assign it to a particular Legionella spp. In the case of extraction column contamination, only a few columns of the same lot may be contaminated and not the entire lot. This means that multiple negative controls are required for optimal specificity, including extraction controls as well as no-template controls. Changing reagents or using specific DNA extractors may help reduce extraneous contamination (75). The false-positive reactions due to reagent contamination are usually due to low levels of contaminants, making reducing the number of amplification cycles one way to reduce the chances of a false-positive reaction (75). Finally, contamination of specimens with tap water containing Legionella spp. is a concern and has been reported to result in pseudo-outbreaks of LD related to bronchoscopy, for both culture and DNA detection methods (77).

sect1.title: Culture
sect1.para: Optimal yield ofLegionella spp. from clinical specimens usually requires (i) dilution to reduce inhibition by tissue and serum factors, as well as antibiotics; (ii) specimen pretreatment to reduce contaminating microbiota; and (iii) use of selective and nonselective media (Table 2). Practically, this entails the inoculation of a nonselective medium and one or two different selective media, with the specimen untreated, heated at 50°C for 30 minutes, and/or acid pretreated to limit the growth of commensal organisms. Culture of Legionella spp. from normally sterile fluids and tissues, such as pleural fluid, aseptically obtained lung tissue, or blood, is often successful without the use of multiple selective media and specimen decontamination. Dilution (1:10) in tryptic soy broth or distilled water can increase the culture yield of most respiratory specimens. Tissues (about 1 g) are ground in a tissue grinder with 1 ml of broth or distilled water before dilution. Pleural, synovial, and blood culture fluids do not require dilution, but yield may be enhanced by concentration by centrifugation.

Decontamination is required to reduce contaminating microbiota in most sputum and other respiratory tract secretions. This is done by heat treating at 50°C for 30 minutes or adding equal volumes of specimen to KCl-HCl buffer (pH 2.2) and incubating at room temperature (5 min) before plating 100 μl of the suspension onto culture media. The culture medium is sufficiently buffered that the acidified specimen is neutralized upon plating. For specimens critical for epidemiologic purposes, culture yield can sometimes be enhanced by plating multiple 10-fold dilutions of specimens onto a variety of media, using a variety of specimen treatments, such as heat and acid, and by performing coculture with amoebae (78, 79). Finally, it is advisable to centrifuge samples to concentrate any Legionella contained (3,000 ± 100 g for 15 min).

sect1.title: Inoculation of Plates
sect1.para: Approximately 0.1 ml is inoculated onto each plate, with the bulk of the inoculum applied to the first quadrant. Comparative studies to show whether it is better to streak plates for isolation or to uniformly distribute the inoculum over the entire plate are lacking.

sect1.title: Culture Media
sect1.para: Buffered charcoal yeast extract medium supplemented with 0.1% α-ketoglutaric acid (BCYEα) is used for the isolation and growth ofLegionella spp. BCYEα can be made selective by the addition of antimicrobial agents (Table 2). A variety of antifungal agents are used in the media. Cycloheximide is a poor choice for media used for clinical specimens, as it fails to inhibit Candida albicans. Both anisomycin and natamycin inhibit more yeasts than cycloheximide. Optimal yield of Legionella spp. from clinical specimens requires the use of different media, one plate with nonselective medium (BCYEα) and one or two with selective media, e.g., BMPA (BCYEα medium containing cefamandole, polymyxin B, and anisomycin) or PAV (BCYE with polymyxin B, anisomycin, and vancomycin). BMPA is an excellent selective medium for the majority of L. pneumophila strains, but the cefamandole present in the medium inhibits the growth of some other Legionella spp. and, rarely, L. pneumophila strains. PAV is required for optimal growth of some Legionella spp. other than L. pneumophila BCYE +AB is composed by BCYE and polymyxin B sulfate, sodium cefazolin, and pimaricin (syn natamycin). According to ISO 11731:2017 (Water quality: Enumeration of Legionella. ISO 11731: 2017.), it is reccomended for water with a low concentration of interfering microorganisms and a high or low concentration of Legionella.

Quality control testing of media is required before they are put into use. Growth of bacteria includingEscherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus should be markedly suppressed compared to the initial colony-forming units inoculated to the plate.

sect1.title: Medium Incubation
sect1.para: Inoculated media are incubated at 36 ± 1°C in humidified air by taping a container of sterile distilled water to the inside of the incubation jar. A small amount of CO2 supplementation (2 to 5%) may enhance growth of some fastidious Legionella spp., such as L. sainthelensi and L. oakridgensis, but higher CO2 levels (>5%) may inhibit growth.

sect1.title: Plate Inspection
sect1.para: Legionella colonies may appear on culture plates after 48 h of incubation. Some rarely isolated Legionella spp. may require up to 14 days of incubation before growth appears, but this is a rare event. Regardless, it is reasonable to inspect culture plates on days 2, 4, 6, 8, and up to day 10, and then again on day 14 if Legionella species is suspected by NAAT. Pseudomonas aeruginosa colonies that resemble Legionella spp. may appear before 48 h. Proper observation of culture plates requires a dissecting microscope illuminated with direct light aimed at the plate surface at approximately a 30° angle, as very young Legionella colonies are small and difficult to see with the naked eye.

The size and morphology ofLegionella colonies change with time. Very young colonies (day 3) are flat, entire, and 0.5 to 1 mm in diameter and, when observed using a dissecting microscope and incident visible light, usually have a speckled blue (with the appearance of the cloudy center of an ice cube), blue-green, or red color. By day 4, colonies become smooth, convex, iridescent, entire, and about 1 to 3 mm in diameter, and look opal-like when observed with a dissecting microscope (Fig. 2). A colony is creamy when a loop is inserted and then removed. Colonies are not normally dry or do not usually come away as whole. Unlike several mimics, the edges of the colonies often possess the typical ground-glass or wet-sugar appearance synonymous with Legionella spp. Colonies will continue to increase in size to up to 5 to 7 mm, become umbonate, sometimes with a tuberculated or inhomogeneous texture, and develop spreading edges; their iridescent nature may be lost at this stage. It is these late-stage colonies that are most difficult to distinguish from non-Legionella spp., making regular plate observation crucial for accurate detection. Although rare, some Legionella colonies do not change morphology with prolonged incubation.

sect1.para: Biosafety level 2 precautions should be used for manipulation ofLegionella cultures. It is safe to inspect culture plates, pick suspect colonies, and subculture them on an open bench in a properly ventilated laboratory. Making an organism emulsion on microscope slides for the purposes of Gram staining can also be safely carried out on an open bench. However, vortexing suspensions, sonication, tissue grinding, and manipulations that may result in generation of high-concentration aerosols should be performed in a biological safety cabinet. No cases of laboratory-acquired LD have been reported.

sect1.title: Initial Workup of Suspect Colonies and Look-Alike Bacteria
sect1.para: Colonies suspected of beingLegionella spp. can be stained with Gram stain to ascertain that the bacteria are small and sometimes filamentous Gram-negative rods. A small amount of the colony should be emulsified evenly in sterile water or saline on a glass slide, and basic fuchsin should be used as counterstain. Depending on colony age and species, Legionella can vary in size from short rods (0.5 by 5 μm) to very long filamentous bacteria 1 by 25 μm. Suspect Gram-negative bacteria should be plated to two different media, BYCEα and either tryptic soy blood agar (TSBA) or BCYEα made without L-cysteine (BCYEα–L), in approximately equal amounts in a small (1-cm2) area; eight or more isolates can be plated to each plate if needed (Fig. 3). Legionella spp. should grow in 16 to 36 h on BCYEα medium but not on TSBA or BCYEα–Lmedium; this takes advantage of the L-cysteine growth dependence of Legionella spp. Rare Legionella spp. partially lose growth dependence for L-cysteine upon serial passage but, even so, grow more poorly on BCYEα–L than on BCYEα; these species include L. nagasakiensis, L. oakridgensis, and L. jordanis, which have been rarely reported to cause LD. TSBA performs almost as well as does BCYEα–Lfor determining L-cysteine dependence for clinical isolates. Interestingly, Brucella blood agar will support L. pneumophila growth almost as well as BCYEα medium, and other blood-containing media have been described to do the same (80).

sect1.para: Common mimics ofLegionella colonies on BCYEα plates include Eikenella corrodens, P. aeruginosa, Flavobacterium spp., Sphingomonas spp., and some Bacillus spp. However, Francisella tularensis is the only Gram-negative bacterium other than Legionella spp. that exhibits L-cysteine growth dependence. Adding to the confusion is that some serotyping reagents for Legionella spp. may cross-react with F. tularensis.

Microbiologists should know that some pathogenic fungi and higher bacteria grow well on BCYEα medium, presenting both potential biohazards and the opportunity to diagnose unsuspected infections includingCoccidioides spp., Blastomyces dermatitidis, Nocardia spp., and rapidly growing mycobacteria (81). More information on the culture of Legionella can be found in ASM Clinical Microbiology Procedures Handbook (48).

sect1.title: Basic Identification
sect1.para: Identification ofLegionella spp. in a clinical laboratory is optimally performed by observation of visual morphology, agglutination methods (82, 83), and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) (84).

DNA sequence-based methods such asmip species identification, SBT or WGS, and specific serotyping are best done at a reference or public health laboratory. Latex agglutination reagents can identify L. pneumophila serogroups 1 through 15 and a range of common Legionella species. In recent years, MALDI–TOF MS has emerged as a rapid and inexpensive technique for species identification through the analysis of ribosomal protein patterns. This technique has improved the routine practice of clinical microbiology laboratories, replacing most traditional biochemical or molecular techniques (84). MALDI-TOF MS has been evaluated for the species-level identification of Legionella spp. and has high overall sensitivity (96.8%) if the species are included in the database (85). Most systems now accurately identify the most common Legionella spp. but do not detect all Legionella species; potential unusual species should be forwarded to a reference laboratory for identification.

Prior to attempting identification of bacterial isolates, the plate should be illuminated with 365 nm UV light in a darkroom; someLegionella spp. other than L. pneumophila fluoresce a brilliant bluish white and some a brilliant red; such bacteria may be best identified by a reference laboratory as they are not L. pneumophila. L. pneumophila fluoresces a very pale yellow-green, usually with diffusion of the fluorescent pigment into the culture medium; this is not specific to this species, and sometimes young cultures are nonfluorescent.

For identification, MALDI-TOF MS is most commonly used. In some labs, serologic identification using FDA-cleared fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-labeled monoclonal antibody to all serogroups ofL. pneumophila is used (Monofluo; Bio-Rad). A non-FDA-cleared FITC-labeled L. pneumophila Sg 1 (Philadelphia 1 strain)-specific polyclonal antiserum is also available (m-TECH, Atlanta, GA; http://www.4m-tech.com/). Serotyping can also be performed using non-FDA-cleared latex agglutination antisera, available in a variety of formats (ThermoFisher, United Kingdom; Denka Seiken, Japan; bioMérieux, France). Since more than 90% of Legionella isolates are L. pneumophila Sg 1, a reagent- and time-saving technique is to first test with L. pneumophila Sg 1 antibody. Testing has to be conducted properly, with the commonest errors being false-negative results because of a prozone phenomenon and false-positive results from contaminated buffers and controls (82). Strains that fail to react with L. pneumophila antibodies are best identified by reference or public health laboratories that have other typing sera and molecular identification methods in use.

Gram-negative rods isolated from clinical specimens that are morphologically consistent withLegionella spp. and are L-cysteine dependent for growth can be presumptively reported as Legionella spp. in the absence of reactivity with typing sera. Gram-negative rods characteristic of Legionella spp. that react with L. pneumophila monoclonal antibody or L. pneumophila Sg 1 polyvalent antibody can be presumptively identified as L. pneumophila or L. pneumophila Sg 1, and identification is finalized if MALDI-TOF MS confirms L. pneumophila. If the isolate does not react with L. pneumophila-specific antibody or if it is a non-Sg 1 L. pneumophila, the isolate should be typed by a reference laboratory. Clinical isolates may be frozen at –80°C in cryovials.

Infections caused by more than oneLegionella spp. or more than one L. pneumophila serogroup have been reported (86). This can sometimes be of importance in identifying the source of an outbreak. Colonies with different morphologies usually represent variants of the same strain but sometimes represent different species and serogroups. Identifying and typing multiple Legionella colony morphologies is the only way to detect such cases.

sect1.title: Advanced Identification
sect1.para: Investigation of LD outbreaks and sometimes single cases of the disease requires knowledge ofLegionella spp. identity and subtype; this identification if needed can be performed by a public health or reference laboratory as long as isolates are available. In addition, strain typing can be performed directly from the original specimen by sequencing of PCR products (73, 87).

Serotyping ofLegionella spp. can be carried out using polyclonal antisera produced by the CDC, other public health agencies, and commercial laboratories (m-TECH, Denka Seiken, ThermoFisher, and others). Either immunofluorescence or agglutination reactions are used, with no clear evidence of superiority of one technique over the other (82). Some producers make polyvalent serum pools that react with a large number of species or serogroups, which can be useful to reduce the number of monovalent antisera used. Specificity of polyvalent antisera has not been studied in great detail, although at least one product reacts with a number of non-Legionella spp. (82). Unfortunately, cross-reactions between different species and serogroups occur even when monovalent antisera are used (82). Non-Legionella spp. also cross-react, including P. aeruginosa, Flavobacterium spp., Bacteroides fragilis, Capnocytophaga ochracea, Bordetella pertussis, Bordetella bronchiseptica, and possibly Burkholderia pseudomallei, making serological identification only presumptive (82).
Monoclonal typing antibodies reduce the number of cross-reactions with Gram-negative bacteria but are commercially available only for identification ofL. pneumophila (82).
The gold standard for the description of newLegionella spp. has been DNA-DNA hybridization analysis, but this is not used to identify already-known species.

Molecular and proteomic identification ofLegionella spp. has replaced other identification techniques in research and specialized laboratories, particularly with the increasing availability of DNA sequencing and MALDI-TOF MS instrument systems.

DNA sequence-based identification methods take advantage of the specific 16S rRNA ormip gene sequences of the different Legionella spp. (87–89). A mip database, procedural instructions including primer sequences, mip sequence alignment software, and other genomic software tools are all available online and can be accessed by contacting the database curators at the UK Health Security Agency (legionella-sbt@ukhsa.gov.uk). Sequence analysis of the 16S rRNA gene has been used to identify several new Legionella spp. (90–93). Partial sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene (500 bp) is able to accurately identify all Legionella spp. to the genus level, all L. pneumophila strains, and about 90% of Legionella spp. other than L. pneumophila to the species level; incorrect species-level identification is a problem for some more unusual Legionella spp. (12, 94). The rpoB gene has been shown to distinguish between species as well as or better than 16S rRNA or mip gene sequencing (95). Intergenic 16S-23S ribosomal spacer PCR analysis has been successful for species identification and does not require DNA sequencing (96); the lack of available databases and the paucity of strain data for many species limit the usefulness of this technique. The relative performances of mip sequencing and full-length 16S rRNA sequencing are not known, but partial 16S rRNA sequencing should not solely be relied on when an unusual Legionella sp. is identified.

NAAT-based methods can be used to distinguish betweenL. pneumophila Sg 1 and other serogroups (97). NAATs can also be used to distinguish Pontiac/MAb 1/MAb 3-1 strains of L. pneumophila Sg 1 from non-Pontiac strains (26, 97).

There can be genotypic discordances for identical serogroups and vice versa (98). Sequencing of L. pneumophila dnaJ appeared to distinguish between some, but not all, L. pneumophila serogroups (96); different serogroups that had similar genotypes have been shown by other methods to have discordant genotypes and serogroups. More extensive testing of this method needs to be performed before it is put into routine use.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Typing ofLegionella spp. is important for public health investigations to identify outbreaks by linking culture-positive environmental sites with clinical isolates during an outbreak. Typing cannot be used by itself to determine the environmental source of an outbreak and must be accompanied by an epidemiological investigation. Otherwise, incorrect conclusions may be made about sources (99). This problem is due to clonal distributions of environmental and clinical Legionella spp. (100–103) and to the poor specificity of some typing techniques.

Monoclonal antibody typing plays a major role in subtypingL. pneumophila Sg 1 isolates and, when used with molecular methods, can increase typing specificity (104–106). Used by itself, monoclonal antibody typing may not be specific enough to distinguish between closely related strains, but this method can be helpful in outbreak situations as a quick screening test of environmental isolates to determine which isolates to genotype.

Sequence-based typing appears to be the most specific and precise molecular subtyping system for bothL. pneumophila and L. pneumophila Sg 1 (104, 107). Pulsed-field gel electrophoresis is now rarely used as SBT and WGS are now preferred methods (100, 108).

WGS is performed in reference and public health laboratories (109, 110). It has high resolution and is therefore useful for potential environmental source attribution. Several methods have been used to determine strain relatedness when using WGS, from single-nucleotide polymorphism analysis to using a core set of genes. The best balance of discrimination and epidemiologic concordance appears to be the use of a core set of around 50 genes of an extended multilocus sequence type (MLST), although MLST using a greater number of core genes (cgMLST) can be useful in certain circumstances (109, 111). As of September 2022, there are no specific databases available for analysis of Legionella species using WGS methods such as cgMLST. As such, in-house curation and validation of databases is required for analysis. The high resolution of WGS has revealed that some outbreak patient isolates thought to be colonized with a single strain are in fact colonized with multiple different strains, which can complicate source attribution (112).

sect2.title: ANTIBODY DETERMINATION
sect2.para: LD can be diagnosed by demonstration of an increase in antibodies to killed bacterial cells (49). The immunofluorescent-antibody assay (IFA) is considered the gold standard method. While most patients develop both IgG and IgM responses, some develop IgM-only, IgG-only, or IgA-only responses, making it necessary to test for total immunoglobulin response and not just IgG. In addition, IgM antibodies may persist for as long as a year after infection, making the presence of IgM a poor marker of acute disease. About 75% of patients with culture-proven health care-related L. pneumophila Sg 1 LD develop seroconversion to the bacterium; the test seems to have higher sensitivity in LD epidemics. Seroconversion requires weeks to months after infection, with only about a 50% seroconversion rate after 2 weeks; for optimal test sensitivity, acute-phase serum should be frozen while convalescent-phase sera are collected at 2, 4, 6, 9, and 12 weeks postinfection. Parallel testing of sera is required for the best specificity. The most specific testing is for seroconversion to L. pneumophila Sg 1 only, and the least specific is the use of polyvalent antigen preparations, with approximate test specificities of 99 and 90 to 95%, respectively. Serologic diagnosis is best used for epidemiologic studies because of the retrospective nature of serologic diagnosis and limitations of test specificity and sensitivity.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES AND SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTING
sect2.para: Antimicrobial agents regarded as effective for treatment of LD are macrolides, fluoroquinolones, and, rarely, rifampin, all achieving adequate intracellular concentrations (113, 114). Acquired antimicrobial resistance in L. pneumophila is rare (115–117). However, a clinical isolate resistant to ciprofloxacin due to a single point mutation in the gyrA gene has been reported (118), and fluoroquinolone resistance has been described during therapy (119). Currently, there is no gold standard for antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) of L. pneumophila. Different methods, particularly with different media, yield different MIC values (120). The use of solid media containing charcoal for AST has been subject to debate, and it has been shown that addition of charcoal to the medium will result in elevated MICs for most relevant agents (121, 122).

However,in vitro testing is only the first step in the eventual goal of determining clinical resistance thresholds that take into account in vivo drug pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, especially as in vitro AST does not take into consideration cellular penetration, which is especially important as L. pneumophila is known to infect and survive in macrophages. The international Legionella community (which includes representation from many international Legionella reference laboratories, as well as from the EUCAST Steering Committee and the CDC) has agreed to the following recommendations. (i) Gradient strip testing on BCYE agar should be discontinued as the recommended methodology, due to higher (and more variable) minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) results when compared with microbroth dilution. (ii) BCYE agar should not be used for serial antimicrobial dilution MIC determination for Legionella due to higher MIC results and antimicrobial sequestration. (iii) Future studies should develop and standardize microbroth dilution as the gold standard for determination of susceptibility of Legionella spp., to enable interpretation and standardization of more accessible concordant methodologies, such as charcoal-free media (e.g., LASARUS). (iv) The Legionella community is in the process of identifying and validating a panel of clinical and environmental reference strains for MIC determination. (v) The Legionella community will endeavor to develop a consensus standard operating procedure, define epidemiological cutoff values, and develop consensus on AST of strains of clinical relevance. (vi) AST for Legionella using a recognized gold-standard methodology will be encouraged as part of a global surveillance for the emergence of resistance. (vii) Phenotypically resistant Legionella strains should be comprehensively analyzed using WGS and other complementary methods to identify new and emerging mechanisms underlying resistance in Legionellaceae (123, 124).

No β-lactam agent or aminoglycoside has acceptable intracellular activity against the bacterium. It is unknown if the intracellular activities of antimicrobial agents againstL. pneumophila can be extrapolated to all other Legionella spp. and to treatment of infections caused by Legionella spp. other than L. pneumophila. Some of these other species may reside in subcellular compartments different from those of L. pneumophila and thus may respond differently to antimicrobial agents (125). However, macrolide and fluoroquinolone antimicrobials appear to be effective for the treatment of LD caused by L. micdadei, L. longbeachae, L. bozemanae, and L. dumoffii (126).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Multiple laboratory methods have to be used for optimal laboratory diagnosis of LD. Culture ofLegionella bacteria from sputum, lung, or other respiratory specimens is the most specific (100%) method for diagnosis of the disease; it is very sensitive (~80 to 90%) in cases of severe untreated disease and insensitive (~20%) in those with mild disease. Culture may be the only positive diagnostic test, especially when Legionella bacteria other than L. pneumophila are causing the infection. Because of the technical difficulty of culture diagnosis, its expense, and its low sensitivity for less severe disease, several alternative diagnostic methods have been developed. The antigenuria assay is more sensitive than culture for the detection of community-acquired disease and especially epidemic disease. Even so, the antigenuria test is only about 60% sensitive under the best of circumstances, performs poorly for detection of health care-related infection, and detects almost exclusively L. pneumophila Sg 1. Antibody detection complements other laboratory diagnostic methods but is retrospective, as it requires seroconversion for greater test specificity and sensitivity. In addition, antibody results obtained using only polyvalent antigens must be viewed with circumspection. Molecular amplification tests are highly sensitive, with FDA-cleared and marketed tests in the United States. However, some labs still use in-house assays that require extra validation before implementation. The performance of laboratory diagnostic tests for non-L. pneumophila Sg 1 LD, restricted by the L. pneumophila Sg 1 specificity of certain assays (e.g., urinary antigen), could lead to underdiagnosis of non-L. pneumophila cases.

A major hindrance to the evaluation of all laboratory diagnostic methods is the lack of a good gold standard for LD. Culture diagnosis, while very specific, is known to be imperfect and of limited sensitivity, especially for epidemic LD. The performances of diagnostic tests are often compared to that of culture diagnosis, which tends to overestimate test sensitivity and underestimate specificity.

Positive cultures for allLegionella spp. are virtually diagnostic of LD, providing there are supportive clinical findings such as pneumonia. In contrast, single serum specimens showing elevated antibodies to Legionella spp. or to L. pneumophila are often not the result of LD. Only increases in titers of antibody to L. pneumophila Sg 1, a test not usually commercially available, are specific enough for diagnosis, but even then, the use of appropriate techniques is required for optimal specificity. Detection of L. pneumophila Sg 1 antigenuria is almost as specific as a positive culture, once heat-labile factors capable of causing false-positive tests are excluded.

A positive urinary antigen or culture, or >4-fold rise in titer toL. pneumophila Sg 1, are all definitive of a case of LD and should be reported promptly to the patient’s clinician to ensure appropriate treatment. Moreover, public health authorities need to be alerted to ensure that they are aware of any developing outbreak situations.
